posts.name: Anupam Chandra
posts.cooked:
Hello @s.anand. There was a post yesterday from @carlton regarding the end term exam (link provided below):

Syllabus and Tips for End Term TDS Tools in Data Science
Syllabus: All 9 modules, All videos Weightage: Roughly equal weightage for all 9 modules Questions: Between 40 to 60 questions Exam time: 1.5 hours Questions will be all brand new set. None from previous PYQs. Kind regards

Since there are a lot of new elements introduced in the course this time and the exam pattern is changing (maybe similar to May 23 ET?), it would be really helpful if we could understand which apps/tools we should cover to manage our prep for the end term.

I ask this because nearly each week lists out a number of tools and apps in the videos. Most of them are mentioned from a utility perspective and it is left up to the student to read up more on the said tools/apps. I’m trying to figure out if there is a way to make the end term exam less open-ended (because it is not open-book like the ROE).

Any advice (including a specific list of tools/apps) would be most helpful.

link_counts.title: Syllabus and Tips for End Term TDS

posts.name: NandanReddy Parnapalli
posts.cooked:
@s.anand @carlton

There are no practice or graded assignments that involve subjective questions in the TDS course. We’re already struggled with the ROE, and now the fact that “None from previous PYQs” applies to TDS is discouraging. If changes are being made, then practice assignments should be introduced for each module to help us understand the types of questions that may appear in the End Term.

posts.name: Smita Dhadhal
posts.cooked:
@iitmanupam @nandanreddyp

You both are talking exactly what almost everyone in this course is feeling … Atleast some guidance would really help all of us .

posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
I realise it sounds scary, but it will not be very deep. Just very broad. Just being familiar with the concepts (on a conceptual level) and familiar with what the tools are, which tool to use, for what purpose, basic functions of those tools (again not deep, just the most important/commonly used functions) will be all that is expected.

Additionally you will have to be familiar with the jargon of data science ( so any time some one mentions a term in the videos, like k anonymity etc) just be familiar with what those mean. Even though the questions are brand new, they will cover the same familiar areas. Data science has not changed that much, but the tools have evolved and the workflows have improved.

Hope that gives a little clarity and confidence. We will take revision sessions for the rest of the term to give you more confidence and prepare you for the end term.

Kind regards

posts.name: Anupam Chandra
posts.cooked:
Thanks for your inputs @carlton, but these are very general in nature. I’m hoping to get an official response on this. I’m using the word “official” because I see that the TAs have started using the same in some of their posts. I guess that is because the TAs found some of their inputs over-ridden by the instructors at a later point of time.

In this case, it would be really helpful if we can get specific inputs from @s.anand. Whether you talk to the Professor and then post it here or he responds directly is not really relevant, as long as the inputs are specific and are posted after a discussion with the Professor.

posts.name: Anand S
posts.cooked:
@carlton and @dibujohn – why don’t you sharing the step-by-step process on how you crafted the final exam questions?

I personally thought the process was fascinating. The more enthusiastic people could replicate the process and get a feel for the kind of questions they’d see (and potentially share with others.)

This would practically give people a series of sample exam papers – without needing to worry about leaks

posts.name: Anupam Chandra
posts.cooked:
@carlton please let us know where and when we can get the information that the Professor was referring to (step by step process on how the final exam questions were crafted).

Since the Professor himself has given a go-ahead, I am assuming that there will be no further concern from your end in sharing the detailed process.

posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
@eram1011 on this post has provided a more comprehensive resource

TDS ET Handwritten Notes Tools in Data Science
These are the handwritten notes I made while learning each module in TDS, including content from the three revision sessions conducted by our TAs for the end term. They don’t include the essential Colab codes since I prefer to record those digitally. For some, these notes could be a lifesaver for end-term prep, while for others, they might just look like a cluttered mess of words . Guess it depends on your learning style! https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/15Z3eI8ANwa8_4NhAsbp…

@AMU has also provided an excellent collation

Syllabus and Tips for End Term TDS Tools in Data Science
